title: ‘Super-storm’ rips through Sydney
text:
Super-storm rips through Penrith as Sydney set for more wet weather February 18, 2017 3:43pm 
A STRONG thunderstorm is moving its way across Penrith this afternoon, bringing hail and damaging wind. 
A separate storm system has already dumped golf ball sized hail at Bowral shortly after 3pm. 
Warnings have been issued for both storms which are forecast to heavily affect Sutherland, Kiama, Campbelltown and Liverpool, and possible lead to flash flooding. 
This comes just 24 hours after Sydney was hit with severe wet weather, which caused blackouts to thousands of homes and wreaked havoc on the roads and public transport. Two storm cells are moving through Sydney, with the red spots representing heavy rainfall. Source: The Daily Telegraph 
Ausgrid is still working to restore power to 6000 homes and businesses today after power was cut off during the storms yesterday. 
A severe thunderstorm smashed through Sydney yesterday, dumping large hailstones in the west, the storms moved speedily across the CBD on its way to the coast. 
A massive number of lightning strikes was recorded across the Harbour City, and there are reports of power outages in and around Saratoga on the Central Coast and in parts of Western Sydney. A bolt appears to strike one of the Harbour Bridge’s pylons. Picture: Matt Lynch / Instagram Source: Instagram The NSWRFS lightning map shows how much lightning struck Sydney yesterday. Source: Twitter 
This summer is set to be one of the hottest on record. 
We have had 10 days above 35C at Observatory Hill, breaking records stretching back to the early 19th century, while February 7 saw more than 40mm of rainfall across Sydney’s suburbs in just half an hour.
